p.text: This Part does not apply to evidence that relates only to the credibility of a witness.
This Part does not apply so far as a proceeding relates to bail or sentencing.
This Part does not apply to evidence of:
the character, reputation or conduct of a person, or
a tendency that a person has or had,
if that character, reputation, conduct or tendency is a fact in issue.
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 394–402, 784–817
ALRC 38 paras 172–177

level.toc-caption: [50,850.10] Character, reputation, conduct or tendency a fact in issue

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,850.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 97(1).

heading.title: Character, reputation, conduct or tendency a fact in issue

p.text: The tendency and coincidence rules do not apply if the tendency and coincidence matters are facts in issue in the proceedings. Facts may be in issue in the proceedings even though they are not the ultimate issues for determination. Character and repute may be matters in issue in defamation proceedings. Character may be put in issue by an accused in defamation proceedings. Tendency may be relevant issue in injunction proceedings. The “tendency” and “coincidence” rules will apply only where the evidence is sought to be adduced for the purpose of proving a “tendency” — and where the “tendency” is only relevant because it, arguably, establishes a basis for inferring that the person acted in a particular way or had a particular state of mind: see s 97(1) of the Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,855] s 95 Use of evidence for other purposes

leg:heading.title: Use of evidence for other purposes

p.text: Evidence that under this Part is not admissible to prove a particular matter must not be used to prove that matter even if it is relevant for another purpose.
Evidence that under this Part cannot be used against a party to prove a particular matter must not be used against the party to prove that matter even if it is relevant for another purpose.
A reference in this Part to doing an act includes a reference to failing to do that act.

Evidence of the character, reputation or conduct of a person, or a tendency that a person has or had, is not admissible to prove that a person has or had a tendency (whether because of the person’s character or otherwise) to act in a particular way, or to have a particular state of mind unless:
the party seeking to adduce the evidence gave reasonable notice in writing to each other party of the party’s intention to adduce the evidence, and
the court thinks that the evidence will, either by itself or having regard to other evidence adduced or to be adduced by the party seeking to adduce the evidence, have significant probative value.
[subs (1) subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[38], effective 1 January 2009]
Subsection (1)(a) does not apply if:
the evidence is adduced in accordance with any directions made by the court under section 100 , or
the evidence is adduced to explain or contradict tendency evidence adduced by another party.

The tendency rule is subject to specific exceptions concerning character of and expert opinion about accused persons ( sections 110 and 111 ). Other provisions of this Act, or of other laws, may operate as further exceptions.
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 5 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 394–402, 809
ALRC 38 paras 172–177
Legislation cited in [50,865.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 “probative value”, “tendency rule”.
This section is defined in the Dictionary as the “tendency rule” for the purposes of the Act. The Dictionary also defines the expression “probative value” .
Legislation cited in [50,865.12] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 97(1)(a).
In order for the evidence to be admissible, the party seeking its admission must prove:
that notice was given in accordance with s 97(1)(a) ; and
that the evidence, either of itself or in combination with other evidence which is to be adduced, has significant probative value.
Legislation cited in [50,865.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 5.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.5.

The notice must comply with Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 5 . In particular, the notice must state the substance of the evidence, details of when the conduct occurred and particulars identifying all witnesses to it that are known to the party giving the notice: see generally R v AN (2000) 117 A Crim R 176; [2000] NSWCCA 372; BC200006805 ; R v AB [2001] NSWCCA 496; BC200108180 ; R v Zhang (2005) 227 ALR 311; 196 FLR 152; [2005] NSWCCA 437; BC200511157 . Additional provisions of the rules of court relating to the form of notice are contained in UCPR r 31.5 .
Legislation cited in [50,865.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 Probative value.

Probative value is defined in the Dictionary. It refers to the ability of the evidence to affect rational assessment of the probability of a fact in issue. By imposing a condition that tendency evidence must have “significant” probative value before it is admissible, the Act intends that relevant and probative tendency evidence must be excluded unless it is also significant. In substance the section introduces a discretionary power to include tendency or propensity evidence that has significant probative value. It has been observed, in the context of the term “significant probative value” as it is used in s 97, that the requirement that the evidence have such value probably does not change the general law which requires, in any event, that conclusions of fact based upon similarities of events be reached by way of reasonable inference, as opposed to mere speculation: see Boniface v SMEC Holdings Pty Ltd [2006] NSWCA 351; BC200610557 at [12] per Hodgson JA. The term “significant probative value” therefore means more than mere relevance but something less than a “substantial degree of relevance”: R v Lockyer (1996) 89 A Crim R 457; BC9604931 ; AW v R [2009] NSWCCA 1; BC200900388 at [47] ; McGaw v Channel Seven Sydney Pty Ltd [2005] NSWSC 1191; BC200510084 ; R v Fletcher [2005] NSWCCA 338; BC200507145 esp at [104] per Rothman J; R v Zhang (2005) 227 ALR 311; 196 FLR 152; [2005] NSWCCA 437; BC200511157 at [139] ; R v Ceniccola [2010] NSWSC 1554; BC201010487 . It is not necessary for there to be a striking pattern or similarity or similarity between the circumstance in question and the circumstance in respect of which the evidence is sought to be adduced. The evidence need only be of a tendency to act in a particular way: R v White (No 3) [2012] NSWSC 467; BC201202875 citing R v Ford (2009) 273 ALR 286; 201 A Crim R 451; [2009] NSWCCA 306; BC200912262 .

In considering the admissibility of such evidence a court should have regard to those authorities decided prior to the enactment of s 97 and which required that the proferred evidence must as a matter of common sense, be clearly and strongly probative of the relevant fact in issue: Zaknic Pty Ltd v Svelte Corp Pty Ltd (1995) 61 FCR 171; 140 ALR 701; BC9501966 ; R v Martin [2000] NSWCCA 332; BC200005078 . However, to the extent that the wording of the present section, in requiring only significant probative value, implies a less stringent limitation than the older authorities, it provides the operative admissibility criterion: see R v Ellis (2003) 58 NSWLR 700; 144 A Crim R 1; [2003] NSWCCA 319; BC200306570 ; Trylow v Cmr of Taxation 2004 ATC 4406; (2004) 55 ATR 408; [2004] FCA 446; BC200401951 ; R v Ngatikaura (2006) 161 A Crim R 329; [2006] NSWCCA 161; BC200603556 . A distinction is to be drawn between evidence of character, reputation and conduct of a person on the one hand (which will prima facie attract the operation of the section) and evidence of objective facts on the other (which will not). Moreover, the section prohibits the use of evidence of conduct etc to prove that a person had a tendency to act in a particular way. It does not prohibit the use of the evidence to prove, by a more direct form of reasoning, that a person did act in a particular way: R v Lumsden [2003] NSWCCA 83; BC200301673 .
Legislation cited in [50,865.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 97, s 97(1), s 98(1).

The distinction between evidence that falls for consideration under the “tendency rule” and evidence that falls under the “coincidence rule” may be difficult to draw in particular cases. It is the difficulty of drawing that distinction that led the ALRC to recommend that tendency or propensity evidence should be admissible in particular cases: see ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 400, 401, 809, 810 and 815; ALRC 38 para 176. The legislative intention appears to be that s 97 is confined to situations where the evidence is proffered to prove the existence of a tendency as such. This is consistent with the difference between the relevant expressions in s 97(1) (“to act in a particular way”) and s 98(1) (“did a particular act”). It may be useful to regard s 97 as referring to a situation where the matter in issue is the person's motive or reason for engaging in particular conduct — eg, their reason for being on premises: see ALRC 26 para 810 fn 79. In such a situation the person's tendency is not itself a fact in issue but is relevant to a fact in issue.

level.toc-caption: [50,865.30] Significant probative value and the possibility of concoction

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,865.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 135, 137.

heading.title: Significant probative value and the possibility of concoction

p.text: Under the common law rules of evidence, similar fact evidence, particularly in sexual assault cases, was not admissible if the evidence was reasonably capable of explanation on the basis of concoction: Hoch v R (1988) 165 CLR 292; 62 ALJR 582 ; R v Pfennig (1995) 182 CLR 461 at 483, 506; 127 ALR 99 ; BRS v R (1997) 191 CLR 275 at 300, 305, 328; 148 ALR 101 . Although similar restraint is appropriate for the exercise of the discretions conferred by ss 135 and 137 of the Evidence Act 1995, the basic question of the admissibility of the evidence is to be determined in the light of the specific provisions of the Evidence Act rather than by inflexible adherence to the common law principles: R v OGD (No 2) (2000) 50 NSWLR 433; BC200006242; [2000] NSWCCA 404 .

level.toc-caption: [50,865.35] Evidence of course of business or habit

p.text: Legislation cited in [50,865.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 “coincidence rule”.

heading.title: Evidence of course of business or habit

p.text: ALRC 26 vol 1 para 806 proposed that specific requirements “consistent with psychological research” should be formulated to assist in achieving predictability about the admission of evidence of usual practice. However, the admissibility of such evidence appears to be unaffected by either the “tendency rule” or the “coincidence rule”. The present rule only applies where the purpose of the evidence is to establish that the person had a “tendency... to act in a particular way”. Rarely will that be the purpose of evidence of usual practice. Moreover, it will not usually be appropriate to describe evidence of a practice or habit as a tendency: see the cases cited in [50,870.25] below. The reasons why the “coincidence rule” does not apply to evidence of practice or habit are also discussed in [50,870.25] .

Evidence that 2 or more events occurred is not admissible to prove that a person did a particular act or had a particular state of mind on the basis that, having regard to any similarities in the events or the circumstances in which they occurred, or any similarities in both the events and the circumstances in which they occurred, it is improbable that the events occurred coincidentally unless:
the party seeking to adduce the evidence gave reasonable notice in writing to each other party of the party’s intention to adduce the evidence, and
the court thinks that the evidence will, either by itself or having regard to other evidence adduced or to be adduced by the party seeking to adduce the evidence, have significant probative value.
One of the events referred to in subsection (1) may be an event the occurrence of which is a fact in issue in the proceeding.
Subsection (1)(a) does not apply if:
the evidence is adduced in accordance with any directions made by the court under section 100 , or
the evidence is adduced to explain or contradict coincidence evidence adduced by another party.
Other provisions of this Act, or of other laws, may operate as exceptions to the coincidence rule.
[s 98 subst Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[39], effective 1 January 2009]
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 5 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 394–402, 806–811
ALRC 38 paras 172–177
This section is defined in the Dictionary as the “coincidence rule” for the purposes of the Act. The Dictionary also defines the expression “probative value”.
Legislation cited in [50,870.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 6.

The notice must comply with Evidence Regulation 2010 reg 6 . In particular, the notice must state the substance of the evidence, details of when each event occurred and particulars identifying all witnesses to the events, so far as they are known to the party giving the notice: Gardiner v R (2006) 162 A Crim R 233; [2006] NSWCCA 190; BC200604582 .
Legislation cited in [50,870.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 101, 97, 98.

Sections 97 and 98 impose a test of “significant probative value” on tendency and coincidence evidence and determinations made under these sections are essentially evaluative and predictive in nature: R v Zhang (2005) 227 ALR 311; 196 FLR 152; [2005] NSWCCA 437; BC200511157 at [141] per Simpson J; R v Fletcher [2005] NSWCCA 338; BC200507145 at [32]–[35] ; Samadi and Djait v R [2008] NSWCCA 330; BC200811316 . “Significant probative value” means something more than mere relevance but less than substantial: R v Lockyer (1996) 89 A Crim R 457; BC9604931 . To be significant it must be of consequence and that will depend on the nature of the fact in issue and the importance of the evidence in establishing the fact: R v Lock (1997) 91 A Crim R 356 at 361; BC9700844 . In ALRC 102 at para 11.48 it is pointed out that ss 97 and 98 provide a preliminary admissibility screen which operates in both civil and criminal proceedings and that, in criminal proceedings there are other requirements that must be satisfied (ie s 101 ): ALRC 102 paras 11.45–11.51.

level.toc-caption: [50,870.25] Evidence of usual practice or habit

heading.title: Evidence of usual practice or habit

p.text: At common law, evidence of an established course of business, or usual practice, was admissible to establish the probable occurrence of a particular event: Cotter v MacLean (1879) 13 Ch D 574 ; Connor v Blacktown District Hospital [1971] 1 NSWLR 713 at 715 (cleaning of floor); Gawne v Gawne [1979] 2 NSWLR 449 (due attestation of documents); Trade Practices Commission v TNT Management Pty Ltd (1984) 56 ALR 647 at 704 (distribution of circulars). The evidence may be adduced to establish the conduct of a particular person: Martin v Osborne (1936) 55 CLR 367; [1936] ALR 261 (conduct of a business). Alternatively, its purpose may be to establish the existence of a particular state of affairs: Connor v Blacktown District Hospital [1971] 1 NSWLR 713 at 715 (cleanliness). The admissibility of the evidence was justified by the relevance of similar conduct as a basis for an inference about the existence, or absence, of the particular fact in issue. Thus in Connor's case Asprey JA said (at 721): “...evidence of a relevant practice may be given by a person who... has regularly and uniformly performed acts, or has observed the regular and uniform performance of acts by others, under the same circumstances and upon the same occasions, so as to make it appear probable in the minds of reasonable men that, given the same circumstances and occasions, the like acts will again be performed”.

ALRC 26 vol 1 para 806 recognised the admissibility of evidence of habit. It proposed that the admissibility of this type of evidence should be subject to admissibility requirements “consistent with psychological research”. However, it is doubtful that evidence of course of business, or usual practice, is really within the “coincidence rule”. This is because the rule only applies where the evidence is adduced for the purpose of establishing that, because of the “improbability of the events occurring coincidentally”, “a person did a particular act”. Evidence of course of business, or usual practice, is rarely adduced for the purpose of establishing the improbability of coincidence between past events and the matters in issue. Indeed the usual purpose of the evidence is to establish the opposite — namely the improbability that, in relation to the matters in issue, there would have been a departure from an established pattern of conduct.
Notices given under section 97 or 98 are to be given in accordance with any regulations or rules of court made for the purposes of this section.
Legislation cited in [50,875.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 31.5.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 67, 99.

UCPR r 31.5 provides that notice for the purposes of ss 67 or 99 must be given within 21 days of notice being given by the court of the matter being placed in a callover for the purpose of fixing a hearing date.
Legislation cited in [50,875.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 97, s 98.
(NSW) Evidence Regulation 2010 regs 5, 6.
As to the form and content of Notices under either s 97 or s 98 , see Evidence Regulation 2010 regs 5 and 6 and the authorities cited at [50,865.15] above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,880] s 100 Court may dispense with notice requirements

leg:heading.title: Court may dispense with notice requirements

p.text: The court may, on the application of a party, direct that the tendency rule is not to apply to particular tendency evidence despite the party's failure to give notice under section 97 .
The court may, on the application of a party, direct that the coincidence rule is not to apply to particular coincidence evidence despite the party's failure to give notice under section 98 .
The application may be made either before or after the time by which the party would, apart from this section, be required to give, or to have given, the notice.
In a civil proceeding, the party's application may be made without notice of it having been given to one or more of the other parties.
The direction:
is subject to such conditions (if any) as the court thinks fit, and
may be given either at or before the hearing.
Without limiting the court's power to impose conditions under this section, those conditions may include one or more of the following:
a condition that the party give notice of its intention to adduce the evidence to a specified party, or to each other party other than a specified party,
a condition that the party give such notice only in respect of specified tendency evidence, or all tendency evidence that the party intends to adduce other than specified tendency evidence,
a condition that the party give such notice only in respect of specified coincidence evidence, or all coincidence evidence that the party intends to adduce other than specified coincidence evidence.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [50,885] s 101 Further restrictions on tendency evidence and coincidence evidence adduced by prosecution

leg:heading.title: Further restrictions on tendency evidence and coincidence evidence adduced by prosecution

p.text: This section only applies in a criminal proceeding and so applies in addition to sections 97 and 98 .

Tendency evidence about a defendant, or coincidence evidence about a defendant, that is adduced by the prosecution cannot be used against the defendant unless the probative value of the evidence substantially outweighs any prejudicial effect it may have on the defendant.
This section does not apply to tendency evidence that the prosecution adduces to explain or contradict tendency evidence adduced by the defendant.
This section does not apply to coincidence evidence that the prosecution adduces to explain or contradict coincidence evidence adduced by the defendant.
The probative value of the evidence must substantially outweigh any prejudicial effect it may have on a defendant: DAO v R [2011] NSWCCA 63; BC201102128 .
Legislation cited in [50,885.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 101, s 79, s 80(a).

The probative value of the evidence in question must be calculated, at least to some extent, by reference to the degree of its relevance to the particular fact in issue. Even if the evidence has significant probative value, it must satisfy the s 101 test of substantially outweighing any prejudicial effect it might have on the accused person. In considering the provisions of s 101, the precise terminology of the section must be applied, as opposed to the previous test at common law: R v Ellis (2003) 58 NSWLR 700; 144 A Crim R 1; [2003] NSWCCA 319; BC200306570 .

Nevertheless, evidence that touches on the ultimate issue may be inadmissible because of a lack of satisfaction that it is truly opinion evidence that satisfies the requirements of s 79 of the Evidence Act. Evidence of that kind may also be rejected because it trespasses upon the judicial function to such an extent as to justify its exclusion in the particular case: Allstate Life Insurance Co v ANZ Banking Group Ltd (No 6) (1996) 64 FCR 79 at 85; 137 ALR 138; BC9601160 ; O'Brien v Gillespie (1997) 41 NSWLR 549 ; Bostik Australia Pty Ltd v Liddiard [2009] NSWCA 167; BC200905523 . These possibilities emphasise the importance of careful scrutiny in the application of s 80(a) , lest the opinion giver asserts an expertise outside their field, or expresses views that are not supported by disclosed and contestable assumptions: R v GK (2001) 53 NSWLR 317; 125 A Crim R 315; [2001] NSWCCA 413; BC200106763 ; Roads and Traffic Authority of New South Wales v Barrie Toepfer Earthmoving & Land Management Pty Ltd [2012] NSWSC 916; BC201206371 .
The provisions of the section do not apply to tendency evidence which is adduced by an accused person in criminal proceedings: R v Lockyer (1996) 89 A Crim R 457; BC9604931 .
